quizzes.question: True or False: Swift code works side-by-side with Objective-C code.
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Welcome to Swift![/h1]

[b]Swift [/b]combines the best of C and Objective-C.

It's ideal for creating new apps and works seamlessly with Objective-C, so it's compatible with apps previously created in that language. 
[note]Swift is ready for your next iOS and OSX project - or for addition into your current app - because Swift code works side-by-side with Objective-C.
We will be covering [b]Swift version 2[/b] in this course.[/note]

quizzes.question:
Fill in the blanks to print the value of the variable to the screen:
[!raw!]
{0}("Your name is {1}(yourName)")
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]"Hello World"[/h1]

Printing text is easy:[code format="swift" ]print("Hello, world!")[/code]
To print the value of a variable inside a text, place it in parentheses, and insert a backslash just prior to the opening parenthesis:[code format="swift" ]print("The value is \(myVariable)")[/code]You do not need the backslash for printing only the variable value:[code format="swift" ]print(myVariable)[/code]
[note]Use of the semi-colon (;) following each statement is fully optional in Swift, unless you wish to place several independent statements on a single line, in which case the semi-colon is required.[/note]

quizzes.question:
Fill in the blank to create a single-line comment within the code:
[!raw!]
{0}prints a text
print("Welcome to Swift")
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Comments[/h1]

The Swift compiler ignores [b]comments[/b], which are used to include non-executable text in your code that may be used as a reminder or note-to-self.
A single-line comment opens with two forward-slashes (//): [code format="swift"]// this is a comment[/code]
A multiline comment begins with a single forward-slash, followed by an asterisk (/*). It concludes with an asterisk, then a forward-slash (*/): [code format="swift"]/* this is also a comment, 
but written over multiple lines */[/code]
[note]Multiline comments in Swift can be nested within other multiline comments.[/note]

quizzes.question: Which Xcode tool runs Swift code?
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]The Tools[/h1]

To build apps with Swift, you will need a [b]Mac [/b]computer (OS X 10.10 or later), running the latest version of [b]Xcode, [/b]which features [b]Playgrounds[/b], a powerful tool that allows you to run Swift code with ease.

To download and install the latest version, go to https://developer.apple.com/xcode/downloads/.
Open Xcode, and click the [b]Get started with a playground[/b] button: [img id="2066" width="70%"] 
This will open the editor, which enables you to run and test your code. The code's result displays in the sidebar.
[note]Alternatively, [b]free [/b]Swift compilers that allow you to run code right in the browser are available online.[/note]
